gitActivity.lastCommitMessage: Add 3 P0 concurrency categories: timeout-missing, retry-storm, idempotency-missing
recentCommits: Add 3 P0 concurrency categories: timeout-missing, retry-storm, idempotency-missing
Add 3 input domain categories: boundary-testing, null-undefined, injection-fuzzing
Add 3 concurrency domain categories: race-condition, deadlock, thread-safety
Add security categories: ldap-injection, ssrf, timing-attack
Add security categories: csrf, xxe, command-injection, deserialization
Add first 3 security categories: sql-injection, xss, path-traversal
Implement CategoryStore with CRUD, indexing, and search
Initial TypeScript project structure with Zod schemas

suggestionHistory.suggestion: Implement the remaining resource management category definitions. Create YAML files for: file-descriptor-leak, connection-pool-exhaustion, cpu-throttling, and disk-quota-exceeded. Each should have detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and 3+ examples.

Create 3 P0 resource domain categories: memory-leak, file-handle-leak, and connection-pool-exhaustion. Each should have detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, pytest/jest templates, and 3+ real-world examples showing vulnerable code and tests.

Add the remaining 3 P0 categories for concurrency domain: timeout-missing, retry-storm, and idempotency-missing. Create YAML definition files in src/categories/definitions/concurrency/ following the pattern of existing categories like race-condition.yml

Create 3 input domain categories for pinata: 'boundary-testing' (test numeric/string limits), 'null-undefined' (missing value handling), and 'injection-fuzzing' (malformed input). Each needs YAML with id, metadata, 3+ detection patterns, test templates for pytest/jest, and 3+ examples with vulnerable/test code.

Create concurrency domain categories. Start with race-condition, deadlock, and thread-safety categories. Each needs: YAML definition with metadata, 3+ detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and 3+ real-world examples. Place in src/categories/definitions/concurrency/

Create 8 data domain category definitions in src/categories/definitions/data/. Include: 1) data-truncation (varchar limits, integer overflow), 2) null-handling (null vs empty, null propagation), 3) encoding-mismatch (UTF-8 vs Latin1, emoji handling), 4) precision-loss (float arithmetic, currency rounding), 5) data-race (read-write conflicts, lost updates), 6) schema-migration (column drops, type changes), 7) bulk-operation (batch insert failures, partial commits), 8) data-validation (regex DoS, constraint violations). Each needs detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and 3+ real examples.

Run 'pnpm test' to see which tests are failing, then fix them. Start with any import/module resolution errors, then schema validation issues, and finally the security category tests. Make sure the YAML files match the expected schema structure.

Create 3 more security category YAML files in src/categories/definitions/security/: 1) ldap-injection.yml for LDAP query injection vulnerabilities, 2) ssrf.yml for Server-Side Request Forgery attacks, and 3) timing-attack.yml for timing-based security issues. Follow the same structure as existing categories with detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and at least 3 examples each.

Create the next batch of security categories: csrf, xxe, command-injection, and deserialization. Each should have detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and 3 real-world examples with CVE references where applicable.

Create the data/categories directory structure and implement the first 3 security categories as YAML files: sql-injection, xss, and path-traversal. Each should have detection patterns for Python/TypeScript, test templates for pytest/jest, and real-world vulnerable code examples.

Create the category content for Week 3 of Phase 1. Start with security domain categories: sql-injection, xss, and path-traversal. Create YAML files in data/categories/security/ with full detection patterns, test templates for pytest/jest, and concrete vulnerable/secure code examples. Reference the schema types and ensure each category has at least 2 detection patterns and 2 test templates.

Implement the CategoryStore class in src/categories/store.ts following the gameplan. Create a class with: load categories from YAML files, CRUD operations (create, read, update, delete), validation using existing Zod schemas, and in-memory indexing by domain/level/language. Include corresponding tests in tests/categories/store.test.ts using vitest.

Implement the CategoryStore class in src/categories/store.ts. Include: constructor that loads categories from YAML files, CRUD methods (get, list, search), indexing by domain/level/language, full-text search, and validation on load. Use the Result type for error handling. Reference gameplan.md Week 2 tasks.

Create the initial TypeScript project structure for Pinata with src/, tests/, and types/ directories. Implement the category schema (id, name, domain, level, severity) and detection pattern schema as TypeScript interfaces. Use Zod for runtime validation. Include a basic tsconfig.json and package.json with necessary dependencies.

Create .cursorrules for Pinata focusing on the taxonomy engine architecture. Define: 1) TypeScript interfaces for Category, DetectionPattern, TestTemplate schemas from gameplan week 1, 2) File structure: src/core/taxonomy/, src/schemas/, tests/, 3) Naming conventions for category IDs (e.g., sec.injection.sql), 4) Testing requirements: unit tests for all CategoryStore operations, 5) Documentation format for each category entry

Create a .cursorrules file for Pinata. Include: TypeScript/Python conventions, schema-first development approach, test-driven mindset (dogfooding our own tool), modular architecture for the 5 phases (Taxonomy Engine, Test Templates, CLI Scanner, Framework Integration, Dashboard). Reference the category domains from brainlift (network, database, auth, time, observability).

Create a .cursorrules file for Pinata, a test coverage analysis tool. Include: TypeScript/Python conventions, modular architecture for taxonomy engine/CLI/dashboard, testing requirements (unit + integration), code organization (src/taxonomy, src/cli, src/templates), and patterns for extensible category system. Focus on clean interfaces between the taxonomy store, detection patterns, and test template generation.

Create a .cursorrules file for Pinata. Use TypeScript with strict mode, ESLint, and Prettier. Set up conventions for schema validation (Zod), file organization (src/categories, src/core, src/cli), testing (Vitest), and documentation. Include rules for type safety, error handling patterns, and consistent naming for category/pattern/template schemas.

Create a GAMEPLAN for Pinata. Break down the implementation into phases: 1) Core taxonomy engine with categories/subcategories, 2) Test generation templates for each category, 3) CLI tool for scanning projects and identifying missing tests, 4) Integration with popular test frameworks (Jest, pytest, etc), 5) Reporting dashboard showing coverage by risk domain. For each phase, list specific tasks, dependencies, and rough time estimates.

Complete the PRD Success Metrics section. Include: adoption metrics (WAU targets, integration milestones), quality metrics (incident reduction %, coverage improvement), business metrics (time saved, ROI). Add sections for: Core Features (test category browser, coverage analyzer, CI/CD integration), Technical Requirements (language support, performance targets), and Timeline/Milestones.
